title: Woman who failed sobriety test claimed her brother fed her meth-laced sandwich
text:
An Arkansas woman claims she failed a sobriety test during a traffic stop because her brother gave her a sandwich laced with meth and spiked her drink.

Elizabeth Catlett, 29, was pulled over in Hot Spring on Sunday at 6.30am when she pulled out of a driveway without her headlights on.

When the officer stopped the vehicle at a nearby intersection and approached it, he could smell marijuana, according to a probable cause affidavit.

The officer noted that she was moving about the vehicle 'in a quick, nervous manner.'

Elizabeth Catlett, 29 (left), has been arrested along with Don Furr, 33 (right), on meth-related charges and accused her brother of feeding her a meth-laced sandwich

KATV reported that Catlett's brother, 33-year-old ex-convict Don Furr, was riding in the passenger seat.

Catlett, who had track marks on her arm, also told police her brother had often plied her with meth-laced drinks

When the officer searched Catlett, he allegedly found in her pocket a plastic bag containing several other plastic bags, a straw cut into a shorter length and scraps of paper, according to the affidavit cited by The Sentinel Record.

The driver told the cop the items did not belong to her and that ‘someone else put it there.’

A closer look at the paper and straw revealed residue of what appeared to be methamphetamine.

Furr was asked if there was anything else illegal in the vehicle, to which the the man reportedly replied that if there was anything, it would be 'ice' in the console.

A further search of the vehicle turned up a bag containing the same substance as found on the straw and a glass pipe commonly used to smoke meth.

Catlett was then transported to the county jail, where she failed a sobriety test three times. As the woman was being Mirandized, she allegedly accused her brother of feeding her the meth-laced sandwich.

Furr has a lengthy criminal record involving drug-related offenses (pictured in earlier booking photos). He had been convicted in 2017 of meth possession

Catlett went on to say she believed Furr had spiked her drink with the drug the night before – something she said he had done frequently.

She said she felt ‘like she does when she used to use meth,’ Catlett was quoted as telling the cops.

Officers noted that they observed track marks on the woman’s left arm and damage to her teeth consistent with ‘frequent narcotics usage.’

Furr later admitted to using meth with Catlett at around 11pm on Saturday.

Catlett and Furr were both charged with possession with purpose to deliver methamphetamine and four counts of possession of drug paraphernalia.

The woman was additionally charged with driving while intoxicated, driving without headlights and refusal to submit to a chemical test.

Both siblings pleaded not guilty to all charges. Catlett was ordered held on $14,500 bond, while Furr’s bond was set at $13,500. They are due back in court on November 4.

Records indicate that Furr has a long history of run-ins with the law, including in May 2017 when he was convicted of possession of meth and drug paraphernalia, and sentenced to three years' probation.
description: Elizabeth Catlett, 29, was arrested along with Don Furr, 33, on meth-related charges in Hot Springs, Arkansas, early Sunday, after being pulled over by a police officer during a traffic stop.
